questions.question_text: Which keyword is used to declare a variable in C++?
questions.explanation: int is a data type keyword used to declare integer variables.

questions.question_text: What is the entry point function for a C++ program?
questions.explanation: The main function is where the program execution begins.

questions.question_text: How do you print output to the console in C++?
questions.explanation: cout is used with the << operator to print output to the console.

questions.question_text: Which operator is used for assignment in C++?
questions.explanation: The single equals sign is used to assign a value to a variable.

questions.question_text: What is a fundamental data type for storing whole numbers in C++?
questions.explanation: int is used to store integer values.

questions.question_text: Which loop structure executes a block of code a specified number of times?
questions.explanation: A for loop is typically used when the number of iterations is known beforehand.

questions.question_text: What is a pointer in C++?
options: A variable that stores a character
A variable that stores a memory address
A variable that stores a boolean value
A variable that stores a floating point number
questions.correct_answer: A variable that stores a memory address
questions.explanation: Pointers are variables that hold the memory addresses of other variables.

questions.question_text: What is a class in C++?
questions.explanation: A class is a user-defined data type that acts as a blueprint for creating objects.

questions.question_text: Which OOP concept allows a class to inherit properties and behaviors from another class?
questions.explanation: Inheritance is the mechanism by which one class acquires the properties and behaviors of another class.

questions.question_text: How do you dynamically allocate memory for an object in C++?
questions.explanation: The new operator is used for dynamic memory allocation in C++.

questions.question_text: What is the primary difference between a reference and a pointer in C++?
options: Pointers can be null references cannot
References can be reassigned pointers cannot
Pointers store values references store addresses
questions.correct_answer: Pointers can be null references cannot
questions.explanation: Pointers can be null or point to nothing, while references must always refer to an existing object and cannot be null.

questions.question_text: Which STL container provides dynamic arrays that can resize themselves?
questions.explanation: std::vector is a sequence container that encapsulates dynamic size arrays.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a constructor in a C++ class?
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special member function that is automatically called when an object is created to initialize its members.

questions.question_text: What is function overloading in C++?
options: Defining multiple functions with the same name but different return types
Defining multiple functions with different names but the same parameters
Defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameters
Defining a function that calls itself
questions.correct_answer: Defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameters
questions.explanation: Function overloading allows multiple functions to have the same name as long as their parameter lists are different.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a virtual function in C++?
options: To allow a base class pointer to call the derived class version of a function
To prevent a function from being overridden
To ensure a function is always inlined
questions.correct_answer: To allow a base class pointer to call the derived class version of a function
questions.explanation: Virtual functions enable runtime polymorphism, allowing the correct derived class function to be called through a base class pointer or reference.

questions.question_text: Which C++ feature allows writing generic code that works with different data types without code duplication?
questions.explanation: Templates provide a way to write generic functions and classes that operate on different data types.

questions.question_text: What is the primary benefit of using std::unique_ptr over a raw pointer?
options: It allows multiple pointers to own the same resource
It automatically manages memory and prevents memory leaks
It is faster than raw pointers
questions.correct_answer: It automatically manages memory and prevents memory leaks
questions.explanation: std::unique_ptr provides exclusive ownership of a dynamically allocated object and automatically deallocates it when the unique_ptr goes out of scope.

questions.question_text: What is an rvalue reference in C++ primarily used for?
options: To allow modification of const objects
questions.explanation: Rvalue references are used to bind to temporary objects (rvalues) and enable move semantics, which can improve performance by moving resources instead of copying them.

questions.question_text: What happens if an exception is thrown in C++ but not caught by any try-catch block?
options: The program prints a warning and continues
questions.explanation: If an exception is thrown and no matching catch block is found, the program will terminate, typically by calling std::terminate.

questions.question_text: Which C++ cast operator is used to safely convert a base class pointer to a derived class pointer at runtime?
questions.explanation: dynamic_cast is used for safe downcasting in polymorphic class hierarchies, performing a runtime check to ensure the conversion is valid.
